Cable & Connector Database

Demystifying USB-C, Thunderbolt, HDMI, and more. Because the same connector can mean wildly different capabilities.

Connector Categories

Browse connectors by category or search for specific types. All data is sourced from official specifications and standards bodies.

USB

View All

USB-A, USB-B, USB-C, Mini, and Micro variants. The most confusing connector family.

Micro USB

USB Micro-B

USB-IF

Max Speed

5 Gbps

Max Power

4.5W

Connector

5 pins, 6.85×1.8mm

Common Uses

Older Android smartphones (pre-2016) E-readers (Kindle) Bluetooth speakers and headphones +5 more

⚠️ USB 3.0 Micro-B is a completely different, wider connector than USB 2.0 Micro-B

Micro USB was mandated by the EU in 2009 as a common charging standard, leading to its widespread adoption on Android phones. It was designed to be more durable than Mini USB with a rated 10,000 insertion cycles. However, its non-reversible design and fragile-feeling connector led to its replacement by USB-C starting around 2015-2016.

Mini USB

USB Mini-B

USB-IF

Max Speed

480 Mbps

Max Power

2.5W

Connector

5 pins, 6.8×3mm

Common Uses

Digital cameras (older models) MP3 players (early 2000s) Older GPS devices (Garmin) +5 more

⚠️ Mini USB is larger and taller than Micro USB - they are not interchangeable

Mini USB was introduced with USB 2.0 in 2000 and was the standard small device connector before Micro USB. It was officially deprecated by USB-IF in 2007 due to durability concerns and the desire for an even smaller connector. However, many devices continued to use it for years, and some niche devices still ship with Mini USB ports today. The PS3 controller's use of Mini USB kept it relevant longer than expected.

USB-A

USB Standard-A

USB-IF

Max Speed

10 Gbps

Max Power

4.5W

Connector

9 pins, 12×4.5mm

Common Uses

Desktop computers Laptops (host ports) Wall chargers +5 more

⚠️ USB 3.x USB-A has 9 pins but is backwards compatible with 4-pin USB 2.0 cables and devices

USB-A is the original USB connector and remains ubiquitous on host devices. While being phased out in favor of USB-C, it will remain common for years due to the massive installed base. The connector was intentionally designed to be non-reversible to ensure proper power delivery orientation, though this is often cited as a design flaw compared to USB-C's reversibility.

Video

View All

HDMI, DisplayPort, DVI, VGA, and Thunderbolt video connections.

DisplayPort

DisplayPort

VESA

Max Speed

77.4 Gbps

Max Power

1.65W

Connector

20 pins, 16.1×4.76mm

Common Uses

Computer monitors Graphics cards Laptops (business/professional) +4 more

⚠️ DisplayPort and Mini DisplayPort have identical capabilities - only the connector size differs

DisplayPort is technically superior to HDMI for computer use, with higher bandwidth, daisy-chaining support, and royalty-free licensing. However, HDMI dominates consumer electronics. DisplayPort Alt Mode over USB-C is increasingly common, making USB-C the de facto DisplayPort connector on modern laptops. DisplayPort 2.1 with UHBR 20 mode offers nearly 4x the bandwidth of HDMI 2.1.

HDMI

High-Definition Multimedia Interface

HDMI Forum

Max Speed

48 Gbps

Max Power

0.275W

Connector

19 pins, 13.9×4.45mm

Common Uses

TVs Monitors Gaming consoles (PS5, Xbox Series X) +6 more

⚠️ HDMI 2.1 ports may not support all 2.1 features - manufacturers can pick and choose which features to implement

HDMI has been the dominant consumer A/V connector since the mid-2000s. The transition to HDMI 2.1 has been confusing because manufacturers can implement subsets of features. When buying a TV or monitor for gaming, verify specific feature support (VRR, ALLM, 4K@120Hz) rather than just checking for 'HDMI 2.1' branding.

Audio

View All

3.5mm, 6.35mm, XLR, RCA, and optical audio connectors.

3.5mm

3.5mm Audio Jack (1/8 inch)

IEC 60603-11

Max Speed

0 Mbps

Connector

4 pins, 3.5×3.5mm

Common Uses

Headphones Earbuds Smartphones (older models) +6 more

⚠️ TRS (3 conductors) and TRRS (4 conductors) look nearly identical but aren't fully compatible

The 3.5mm jack has been the universal audio connector for decades, but is being phased out of smartphones in favor of USB-C or wireless. The connector originated from 19th century telephone switchboards (the 6.35mm version) and was miniaturized for transistor radios in the 1950s. Despite being 'obsolete' it remains ubiquitous due to simplicity and universal compatibility.

6.35mm

6.35mm Audio Jack (1/4 inch)

IEC 60603-11

Max Speed

0 Mbps

Connector

3 pins, 6.35×6.35mm

Common Uses

Electric guitars and basses Guitar amplifiers Audio interfaces +6 more

⚠️ TS and TRS look almost identical but serve different purposes - TS for instruments, TRS for balanced or stereo

The 6.35mm jack dates back to 1878 telephone switchboards, making it one of the oldest electrical connectors still in common use. Its durability and simplicity have kept it standard in professional audio and musical instruments. While consumer electronics moved to 3.5mm, the 1/4" connector remains dominant in professional audio where its larger size allows for more robust connections.

RCA

RCA Connector

None (de facto standard)

Max Speed

3.072 Mbps

Connector

1 pins, 8×8mm

Common Uses

Home theater receivers DVD/Blu-ray players Turntables +6 more

⚠️ Audio RCA cables and video RCA cables may look identical but video cables need 75Ω impedance

RCA connectors were introduced by the Radio Corporation of America in the 1930s for internal phonograph connections. They became the consumer A/V standard through the 20th century. While being replaced by HDMI and digital connections, RCA remains common on audio equipment, especially subwoofers, turntables, and home theater receivers. The connector's simplicity is both its strength and weakness - easy to use but unbalanced and prone to interference.
